newsitem.title: GERMANY: Demand for N.Europe rapeseed underpins prices.
newsitem.headline: Demand for N.Europe rapeseed underpins prices.

text.p: Northern European rapeseed prices are holding up on local demand, ignoring a looming near-term reversal in the Chicago soy complex, brokers said on Friday.
"Rapeseed from the old and new crops sold well in the past week and prices in the next few weeks look stable because of the tight oilseeds scenario," one said.
Processors were relatively well covered with sunseed and soybeans but this did not weigh on the rapeseed price because of generally good crushing demand, he added.
Old crop buyers free Hamburg were at 480 marks a tonne, five marks higher than a week ago.
New crop buyers free Hamburg were at 448 marks, up three from last Friday.
Prices were seen easing with the arrival of Brazilian new crop soybeans but that was expected only at the end of March or early April.
Brokers also noted active rapeseed dealings on the Matif exchange, where May was up five marks at 480 and August up three at 458.
Farmers in eastern Germany reported active negotiations on pre-harvest 1998 sales contracts.
March rapeseed buyers at points other than Hamburg were at 470-480, April buyers at 480 and August buyers at 440-455.
March rape meal ex Hamburg mills was at 31.50-32.00 marks per 100 kg, April at 31.25 and May-first half July at 29.75.
German rape oil sellers quoted March at 89.00 marks per 100 kg, April at 90.25 and May-July at 91.50.
